thread.title: Mahoney: Councilor failed his district; Bey: 'What a liar'
thread.title_full: Mahoney: Councilor failed his district; Bey: 'What a liar' | syracuse.com

author: Michelle Breidenbach | mbreidenbach@syracuse.com
title: Mahoney: Councilor failed his district; Bey: 'What a liar'
text:
SYRACUSE, N.Y. - A war of words has broken out between Onondaga County Executive Joanie Mahoney and Syracuse Common Councilor Khalid Bey as they head into the Nov. 3 election.
The two are, of course, not running against each other.
But Mahoney has said she would support a challenger to Bey because she believes he did not do enough to support the ill-fated Syracuse University stadium project last year.
Bey replied by calling the county executive a liar who spews venom and has exposed herself as insecure and a coward.
"It's her character that I now have on trial," he said.
It started when Mahoney, a Republican, expressed her disappointment with Bey, a Democrat, and said she would support community activist Mary Nelson, another Democrat who is challenging Bey in the 4th district.
The reason goes back to the wrecked stadium deal, Mahoney said.
In January 2014, Syracuse University, Mahoney, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, real estate developers and other insiders were negotiating behind the scenes to build a $500 million stadium on a vacant lot near downtown Syracuse – the heart of the 4th council district.
Mahoney said Bey let an opportunity pass by for his district. He was telling Mahoney privately that he was supportive, but Mahoney said she was disappointed that he did not make enough of a case in public when they needed it most.
Bey was outraged at the suggestion.
"What a liar," he said.
Bey is someone who normally does not take sides in public.
But he said, "If Joanie wants to get into that kind of debate, I would love to. I assure you, it's one she won't win."
Bey said he worked hard to galvanize other city councilors in favor of the stadium and tried to convince Mayor Stephanie Miner, even though it strained their friendship. He said his support is a matter of public record.
"The city must seize this opportunity now," Bey wrote in a letter to the editor with other councilors.
Miner confirmed Bey's story. He argued that a new stadium would be good economic development for the city. Miner said she had not seen an instance of a stadium as solid economic development anywhere in the country.
The plan fizzled.
Miner said she still believes Bey is a good advocate for the district.
Bey tells a different story about why Mahoney turned against him. He said Mahoney went as far as hunting for someone to oppose him in this year's election.
Bey said the reason goes back to his support for Toby Shelley – the Democrat who is challenging Mahoney this year.
Just after Democrats designated him to be their candidate this year, Shelley was Quote: d in the Syracuse New Times in an article about racial profiling that he thought it was okay for police to stop and ask someone who looked different how he was doing.
Some Democratic leaders were outraged enough to drop Shelley as the party's endorsed candidate.
Bey said Mahoney pushed him to denounce Shelley.
Bey, who is black, said he talked to Shelley himself and made his own judgment that the article twisted Shelley's comments out of context and it did not mean Shelley was racist.
"Even the fact that she thinks she can call me and influence me, shows the arrogance," Bey said. "Shame on her for making that kind of assumption."
Bey went on to say he does not appreciate people who do not live on the South Side of Syracuse who believe they have the best ideas about what is best for the neighborhood.
All that said, Bey took a step back and said Mahoney has done a very good job on behalf of the county.
"For that reason, she shouldn't have to stoop to these kinds of tactics," he said. "In my opinion, her record is enough to make her a formidable opponent, but these kinds of tactics undermine that. It shows that underneath it all, you have a serious, serious lack of confidence."
Mahoney's response to Bey's side of the story, "That's funny."
She said she has never in her life asked anyone to denounce anyone else.
For her part, Nelson bristled earlier this summer when asked about rumors that Mahoney was backing her race. Since then, her campaign spokesman has told a reporter not to contact Nelson anymore.
It is not out of the ordinary for Mahoney to support a Democrat. She famously endorsed Cuomo in his first race for governor. It is unusual, however, for a suburban Republican to support one Democrat against another in the city.
Miner said she has never seen that happen before in local politics. Miner said she wouldn't comment on Mahoney's comments.
"Everybody is allowed to speak their piece, but at the end of the day there is a difference between Republicans and Democrats and I think that is a difference that matters," Miner said.
See who is on the ballot in Onondaga County.
Contact Michelle Breidenbach anytime: Email | Twitter | 315-470-3186
